Nooooooooo! You didn't mention the misnomer that a heart that is in a state of arrest can be restarted by using a defibrillator. It only works if your heart is still at least trying to pump but not doing so properly. When the heart has completely stopped, say from drug overdose, you have to give them a shot of adrenaline directly to the heart to restart that system. At which point you may have to use a defibrillator to reset the rhythm to the correct one, but if the heart is completely out then a defibrillator will do nothing usually.

It's called a baton, Hank. But that wasn't enough to keep my friends from calling it a wand while I was taking conducting classes in college.

OBJECTION!

Orchestras don't need a conductor to stay together. Musicians who play in orchestras and ensembles know how to listen and follow each other very well and it's not uncommon to have a conductor in rehearsal ask them to play the music once or twice without being conducted if they need to listen and work together better. The job of the conductor is the same as a director - make sure everyone is working together properly as you're putting it together. The arm-waving is just in case they lose track.

Also, personal bugbear, tubas are (by necessity) rock steady. As a bass instrument, they are the foundation upon which the orchestra is built and they have a great deal of power to speed up or slow down the music. They would probably be the last people to 'get a little weird', except for perhaps the percussionists, as it is literally their only job to hit the right thing at the right time.

This is, of course, assuming you have competent musicians...

Very nice video except for one thing. You don't always need a defibrilator. Not every cardiac arrest is caused by ventricular fibrilation or pulsless ventricular tachicardia. Ventricular fibrilation and pulsless ventricular tachicardia are shockable rhythms and you need a defibrilator when you see one. But some cardiac arrest victims have pulsless electric activity or asystole. These two are called non-shockable rhythms and as the name implies, you can't (shouldn't) try to defibrilate those. So, you don't always need a defibrilator.

It sounds like the pacemaker cells' activity is extremely constant, fibrillation notwithstanding. But what controls the normal and perfectly healthy fluctuations in heart rate that we see, for instance, between strenuous exercise and rest?

Actually, mostly correct.  Congrats!
Of course, square wave impulses via a defibrillator  are also used to treat asystole.  How about that?  What about the ubiquitous and often-effective chest "thump" which you initially referenced?  Also, you seemed to imply that, in the absence of a defibrillator, CPR would not be effective.  That isn't correct.  Ventricular fibrillation is not the only cause of effective cardiac "arrest", that is, ineffective cardiac rhythm. Many others will spontaneously resolve given enough time.  During that time the brain must be effectively perfused with oxygenated blood.
